title.narrative: CCBRT (Comprehensive Community Based Rehabilitatioin Tanzania) - verksamhetsstöd 2013-2014 "Changing Lives, Changing Communities 2013-2017"
CCBRT (Comprehensive Community Based Rehabilitatioin Tanzania) core support 2013-2014 "Changing Lives, Changing Communities 2013-2017"

description.narrative: CCBRT etablerades 1994 för att förbättra livskvalitet i familjer där familjemedlemmar drabbats av funktionshinder. Sedan dess har en ökad andel av deras arbete inbegripit mödra- och barnhälsa som ett led i att förebygga funktionshinder. En majoritet av personer som lever med funktionshinder i Tanzania är fattiga. Stödet ska hjälpa CCBRT att bygga ett nytt sjukhus för förlossnings- & mödravård.

CCBRT was established in 1994 to improve the quality of life in families affected by disability. Since the organization was founded in 1994, an increasing proportion of their work includes maternal and child health as a step to prevent disability. A majority of people living with disabilities in Tanzania are poor. The support will especially be used to build a new hospital for maternal care.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2014Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: Sweden provided financial support to CCBRT for the fiscal years 2013 and 2014. The total amount provided was MSEK 45. During this period, CCBRT expanded its health care delivery services both in urban and rural areas. This has been achieved in the following ways: 1) CCBRT has built the capacity of local health care personnel and financially supported six partner facilities to provide fistula recovery surgeries in Moshi, Arusha, Kigoma/Kasulu, Peramiho, Songea and Tabora. A total of 1693 maternal health care professionals have been trained. 2. The CCBRT Maternal and Newborn Capacity Building Programme has scaled up support from 16 to 22 health facilities, which jointly covered over 78,000 deliveries during the year. 3. During this period, CCBRT drafted a new strategic Plan for the Maternal and Newborn Healthcare Programme, that outlines the new hospitals target groups, its capacity, operations and services ( clinical services, as well as non clinical support services). It has also incorported the budget and monitoring and evaluation framework. 4. The regional and district led health managers trained by CCBRT have successfully strengthened the capacity of health care professionals and managers at six additional health facilities. Staff at two government health facilities trained by CCBRT are now successfully implementing activities in other facilities independent of CCBRT support. This has demonstrated the importance of the peer to peer model. In addition to all the results above, there has been an increase in the total number of deliveries from 57,966 in 2013 to 78,406 in 2014 at CCBRT supported health facilities. This is a 35% increase. Another success has been the decrease in the number of maternal deaths and a decrease in the rate of stillbirths. The results above highlight key success factors in terms of the overall development objective and the contribution is on track in many areas towards achieving its key objective.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
